questions.text: A 50-year-old man undergoing a renal transplant develops sudden graft failure intraoperatively. The transplanted kidney appears mottled and cyanotic within hours. What is the most likely mechanism involved?
questions.solution: The sudden graft failure with cyanosis during renal transplant is due to a Type II hypersensitivity reaction caused by preformed recipient antibodies targeting donor antigens.

questions.text: A diabetic patient in ketoacidosis develops orbital cellulitis with black nasal discharge and facial swelling. Which of the following fungi is most commonly responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
The most common cause of orbital cellulitis in diabetic ketoacidosis is Rhizopus, due to its angio-invasive nature, leading to rapidly progressive rhinocerebral mucormycosis.

Mucormycosis:

  • An aggressive fungal infection caused by Zygomycetes, mainly:
    • Rhizopus arrhizus (most common)
    • Mucor species
    • Absidia species


  • Pathogenesis:
    • Spores enter via the respiratory tract or the nasal cavity.
    • Germination leads to mycelial growth and local tissue invasion.
    • The fungi invade blood vessels (angioinvasion), causing:
      • Thrombosis
      • Tissue infarction
      • Rapid disease progression with high mortality.
  • Common Sites of Involvement:
    • Rhinocerebral form: Most frequent in diabetic patients, affecting:
      • Nose
      • Paranasal sinuses
      • Orbit (can progress to the brain)
    • Pulmonary mucormycosis: Involves the lungs and blood vessels.
    • Other forms:
      • Cutaneous mucormycosis
      • Gastrointestinal mucormycosis
      • Disseminated mucormycosis
  • Clinical Features:
    • Rhinocerebral Mucormycosis:
      • Facial swelling
      • Blackish nasal discharge
      • Fever
      • Necrosis of the nasal or oral mucosa
      • Potential vision loss and neurological signs
    • Pulmonary Mucormycosis:
      • Cough
      • Fever
      • Hemoptysis
  • Diagnosis:
    • Microscopy:
      • Broad, ribbon-like, non-septate hyphae on histology.
    • Culture:
      • Grows in 3-4 days on Sabouraud dextrose agar.
      • Appearance: Grey-white, cottony colonies.
    • LPCB stain shows:
      • Non-septate hyphae
      • Sporangiophores with a terminal sporangium (spore sac)
  • Treatment:
    • First-line: Intravenous amphotericin B.
    • Surgical debridement for necrotic tissue.
    • Optimal control of underlying conditions, such as diabetes, is essential.

Explanation of other options:

Candida (Option A): Typically causes mucosal or bloodstream infections, not invasive sinus or orbital disease.

Aspergillus (Option C): Can cause invasive sinusitis, but is more common in neutropenic or immunocompromised patients, not specifically linked to DKA.

Trichophyton (Option D): Causes superficial dermatophytosis, not invasive fungal infections.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with new-onset seizures. He has no significant prior medical history. MRI of the brain is shown below. Based on the clinical presentation and the imaging findings, what is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
The image shows multiple calcified cystic lesions in the brain parenchyma, which, along with seizures, is classic for neurocysticercosis caused by Cysticercus cellulosae, the larval stage of Taenia solium.

Explanation of other options:

Taenia saginata (Option B): Causes intestinal infection via undercooked beef; does not cause cysticercosis.

Cysticercus bovis (Option C) is the larval form of Taenia saginata found in cattle; it does not cause human cysticercosis.

Taenia asiatica (Option D): Causes intestinal infection similar to T. saginata, but no known association with cysticercosis.

Reference:

  1. https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/medicine-and-dentistry/cutaneous-amoebiasis#
  2. https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/medicine-and-dentistry/cutaneous-leishmaniasis#
  3. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK507706/

questions.text: An HIV-positive individual presents with persistent watery diarrhea. Stool microscopy with modified acid-fast staining reveals round oocysts measuring 4-6 microns, as shown in the image below. What is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
The presence of small (4-6 micron), round, acid-fast oocysts in the stool of an HIV-positive patient with persistent diarrhea is characteristic of Cryptosporidium infection.

Cryptosporidium:

  • Infective Form:
    • Sporulated oocysts are present in contaminated water.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Immunocompetent individuals:
      • Self-limiting watery diarrhea.
    • Immunocompromised individuals (e.g., HIV patients):
      • Chronic, persistent watery diarrhea.
  • Microscopy Characteristics:
    • Shape: Round, acid-fast oocyst.
    • Size: 4-6 microns.
    • Internal Structure: Contains four sporozoites.
  • Types of Oocysts:
    • Thick-walled oocysts: Shed in feces, involved in transmission.
    • Thin-walled oocysts: Responsible for autoinfection within the host.

Explanation of other options:

Cyclospora (Option B): The oocysts of Cyclospora are larger (8-10 microns), variably acid-fast, and show autofluorescence, unlike the smaller, consistently acid-fast oocysts seen here.

Microsporidia (Option C): Microsporidia spores are much smaller (1-2 microns) and require special stains like modified trichrome; they do not appear as round, acid-fast oocysts.

Cystoisospora (Option D): Cystoisospora oocysts are oval, not round, much larger (24-36 microns), and show autofluorescence, which differentiates them from Cryptosporidium.


Reference:

  1. Etiology and evaluation of diarrhea in AIDS: A global perspective at the millennium - PMC HIV/AIDS-Associated Opportunistic Protozoal Diarrhea - PMC.

questions.text: A 23-year-old patient with a recent history of travel to China and consumption of pickled crab presents with a cough and sputum that is rusty-colored. What is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
The patient's history of consuming pickled crab and presenting with cough and rusty sputum is characteristic of lung fluke infection caused by Paragonimus westermani.

Explanation of other options:

Fasciola buski (Option A): Intestinal fluke causing gastrointestinal symptoms, not respiratory disease.

Fasciola hepatica (Option B): Affects the liver and biliary tract, not associated with pulmonary symptoms.

Schistosoma japonicum (Option D): Primarily causes intestinal and hepatic schistosomiasis, not lung involvement.

choices.text: MHC Class II presents peptide antigens to CD4+ T cells.
MHC Class II presents antigens via the endocytic pathway.
MHC Class II presents antigens derived from within the cell.
MHC Class II molecules are found on antigen-presenting cells.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about MHC molecules is incorrect?
questions.solution: MHC Class II molecules specialize in presenting exogenous antigens, such as those derived from extracellular pathogens, after uptake through processes like phagocytosis or endocytosis.

choices.text: Night-time peripheral blood smear for microfilariae
Duplex ultrasonography of the limb veins

questions.text: A woman from a northeastern state presents with gradually increasing swelling of her upper limb, predominantly involving the proximal part. She has a past history of coronary intervention. On examination, there is no distal edema or signs of deep vein thrombosis. Considering the geographic background and clinical findings, what is the next best investigation?
questions.solution:
The patient's progressive proximal limb swelling, along with residence in a filariasis-endemic area, raises strong suspicion for lymphatic filariasis. A night blood test for microfilariae is the next best investigation, as microfilariae show nocturnal periodicity.

Explanation of other options:

Echocardiography (Option A): Useful for assessing cardiac causes like heart failure or SVC syndrome, but these typically cause bilateral limb swelling, not isolated proximal swelling of one limb as seen here.

Duplex ultrasonography of the limb veins (Option C): Helpful in diagnosing deep vein thrombosis (DVT), but DVT generally presents with distal swelling, pain, and redness, which are not features in this patient.

Electrocardiogram (ECG) (Option D): Evaluates heart rhythm and electrical activity, but does not assist in diagnosing localized limb swelling related to lymphatic causes like filariasis.

Reference:

  1. https://www.cdc.gov/dpdx/lymphaticfilariasis/index.html
  2. https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC6420789/#
  3. https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/medicine-and-dentistry/lofflers-syndrome
  4. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK562300/#

questions.text: A 22-year-old presents with high-grade fever, altered mental status, and a purpuric rash. CSF analysis is performed, and the microscopic image is shown below. Based on the image and clinical findings, what is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
The presence of gram-negative diplococci in CSF, along with fever and purpuric rash, is characteristic of meningococcal meningitis caused by Neisseria meningitidis.

Clinical Features of N. Meningitidis:

  • Initial Presentation:
    • Sudden onset of fever, headache, nausea, vomiting, severe myalgias.
    • Nonspecific rash, sore throat, upper respiratory symptoms.
    • Early symptoms are often mistaken for common viral illnesses.
  • Disease Progression:
    • Rapid deterioration possible; death within hours in severe cases.
    • Later signs:
      • Neck stiffness, photophobia.
      • Petechiae, purpura, hemorrhagic rash.
      • Altered mental status, shock, abnormal skin color.
      • Severe forms: Purpura fulminans, DIC.

Lab Investigations of N. Meningitidis:

  • Cerebrospinal Fluid (CSF) Analysis:
    • Appearance: Cloudy or purulent
    • WBC Count: Elevated (pleocytosis), typically >1,000 cells/µL with neutrophilic predominance
    • Protein: Elevated
    • Glucose: Decreased
    • Gram Stain: Shows gram-negative diplococci
    • Culture: Growth on chocolate agar or Thayer-Martin agar
    • PCR: Detects Neisseria meningitidis DNA
    • Latex Agglutination Test: Positive for Neisseria meningitidis antigens
  • Blood Tests:
    • Culture: Growth of Neisseria meningitidis
    • WBC Count: Elevated leukocytosis with left shift

Explanation of other options:

Pseudomonas aeruginosa (Option B): This is a gram-negative rod, not a diplococcus, and typically causes hospital-acquired meningitis, especially following neurosurgical procedures.

Streptococcus pneumoniae (Option C): It is a gram-positive diplococcus, so gram-negative diplococci on CSF analysis rule it out as the cause.

E. coli (Option D): A gram-negative rod that commonly causes neonatal meningitis but is not associated with gram-negative diplococci or a purpuric rash.

Reference:

  1. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK557831/
  2. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK470537/
  3. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK564298/
  4. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK549849/

questions.text: Which of the following organisms is classified as a Category A bioterrorism threat by the CDC?
questions.solution:
Bacillus anthracis, the causative agent of anthrax, is classified as a Category A bioterrorism agent due to its high potential for widespread dissemination, severe illness, and public panic.

Bioterrorism Agents: CDC Classification:

  • The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) categorizes potential bioterrorism agents into three groups based on how easily they can be spread, the severity of illness they cause, and their impact on public health.

Reference:

  1. Bioterrorism: A Public Health Perspective - PMC
  2. https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC2609859/
  3. https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/16964579/

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presents with bloody diarrhea following the consumption of undercooked beef. Stool culture is performed to identify the causative organism. Which of the following culture media is specifically used to differentiate Escherichia coli O157:H7 from other E. coli strains?
questions.solution:
Sorbitol MacConkey agar is used to differentiate E. coli O157:H7, which appears as colorless colonies due to its inability to ferment sorbitol, unlike other E. coli strains.

Specimen Collection for E. coli Identification:

  • Stool Sample:
    • Used for gastrointestinal infections (e.g., diarrhea, dysentery).
  • Urine Sample:
    • For the diagnosis of urinary tract infections (UTIs).
  • Blood Sample:
    • Collected in suspected septicemia cases.
  • Cerebrospinal Fluid (CSF):
    • Collected for suspected meningitis, especially in neonates.

Laboratory Identification Methods:

  • Microscopy:
    • Gram Staining:
      • coli appears as Gram-negative, pink-colored rods.
      • Useful for rapid, preliminary identification in blood or CSF samples.
  • Culture Methods:
    • General Media:
      • MacConkey Agar:
        • coli shows pink colonies due to lactose fermentation.
    • Selective & Differential Media:
      • Eosin Methylene Blue (EMB) Agar:
        • Typical colonies exhibit a metallic green sheen.
    • Sorbitol MacConkey (SMAC) Agar:
      • Differentiates coli O157:H7 (colorless colonies due to no sorbitol fermentation) from other E. coli strains (pink colonies).

Biochemical Identification (IMViC Tests):


Explanation of other options:

Mannitol salt agar (Option A): Selective for Staphylococcus species due to its high salt content; not used for identifying E. coli.

Xylose lysine deoxycholate (XLD) agar (Option B): Primarily used for isolating Salmonella and Shigella from stool, not for differentiating E. coli strains.

CLED medium (Option D): Designed for urinary pathogens to prevent swarming of Proteus species; does not differentiate E. coli O157:H7 from other E. coli.

Reference:

  1. https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/10419201/

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman from a tribal region presents with high-grade fever for the past 3 days. A peripheral blood smear reveals the findings shown in the image. Based on the clinical presentation and the smear findings, what is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
The clinical history of fever in a patient from a tribal area, along with PBS showing only ring forms and crescent-shaped gametocytes, points towards a diagnosis of Plasmodium falciparum.

Note: In P. falciparum infections, only ring forms and crescent-shaped gametocytes are typically seen in peripheral blood, as other stages are sequestered in deep tissues.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with multiple episodes of vomiting that started approximately 3 hours after attending a birthday party, where he consumed pastries and dairy-based snacks. Other attendees have reported similar symptoms. Which of the following organisms is the most likely cause of his illness?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of multiple episodes of vomiting within 3 hours of consuming dairy-based snacks at a party points towards a diagnosis of Staphylococcus aureus food poisoning.

Staphylococcus aureus:

  • Produces pre-formed enterotoxins, leading to rapid-onset vomiting, typically within 1-5 hours after food consumption.
  • Common food sources include cream-based items (e.g., custards, mayonnaise), meat products, eggs, and improperly stored leftovers.
  • Virulence Factors:
    • Enterotoxin (Superantigen):
      • A major cause of food poisoning.
      • Stimulates the vomiting center via the autonomic nervous system.
      • Most cases are linked to Type A enterotoxin.
    • Protein A:
      • Inhibits opsonization by binding to the Fc region of IgG.
    • Clumping Factor:
      • Responsible for the slide coagulase test.
    • Panton-Valentine Leukocidin (PVL):
      • Destroys neutrophils; associated with severe infections, especially in MRSA.

Explanation of other others:

Clostridium botulinum (Option B): Causes foodborne botulism due to pre-formed neurotoxin, but it presents with descending flaccid paralysis, diplopia, and dysphagia, not rapid-onset vomiting alone. The incubation period is usually 12-36 hours, much longer than the 3-hour window in this case.

Clostridium perfringens (Option C): Typically causes food poisoning with watery diarrhea and abdominal cramps, but vomiting is uncommon. The incubation period is around 8-16 hours, again inconsistent with this patient's rapid symptom onset.

Salmonella typhi (Option D): Causes typhoid fever, which presents with prolonged fever, abdominal pain, and sometimes constipation or diarrhea. Incubation period is 1-2 weeks, making it unlikely to cause symptoms within hours of eating.

Reference:

  1. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK459273/
  2. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK7699/#

questions.text: In the illustrated ELISA technique, which component represents the enzyme conjugate?
questions.solution:
The diagram provided shows a Sandwich ELISA, where the antigen is captured between two antibodies. II represents the enzyme-labeled detection antibody, also known as the enzyme conjugate, which binds to the antigen and catalyzes a color-producing reaction after substrate addition.

  • I → Substrate (e.g., TMB), reacts with enzyme to produce visible signal
  • II → Enzyme-conjugated detection antibody
  • III → Target antigen from the patient's sample
  • IV → Capture antibody, coated onto the well

ELISA (Enzyme-Linked Immunosorbent Assay):

  • A widely used laboratory technique for detecting antigens or antibodies.
  • Known for being sensitive, versatile, simple, and cost-effective.
  • Frequently employed in diagnostic laboratories due to the availability of test kits and automation.

Types of ELISA:

  1. Homogeneous ELISA:
    • Simple, one-step process.
    • No need to separate bound from free fractions.
    • Commonly used for small molecules like drugs.
    • Example: EMIT (Enzyme-Multiplied Immunoassay Technique) for drug screening.
  2. Heterogeneous ELISA:
    • Involves multiple steps, including washing or centrifugation to separate bound and free components.
    • Common method for detecting microbial antigens or antibodies.
    • Example: Standard ELISA tests for infections.

Common ELISA Methods:

  1. Sandwich ELISA:
    • Detects antigens.
    • Uses two antibodies: one for capturing the antigen and another (enzyme-labeled) for detection.
    • Example: Detection of rotavirus antigens in stool samples.
  2. Indirect ELISA:
    • Detects antibodies present in a patient's sample.
    • Example: HIV antibody testing.
  3. Competitive ELISA:
    • Antigen in the sample competes with a labeled antigen for limited antibody binding.
    • Higher antigen levels produce less color (inverse relationship).
    • Example: Detection of small molecules or haptens.
  4. Capture ELISA:
    • Highly specific antigen detection method.
    • Example: Immunometric assays for various antigens.

Applications of ELISA:

  • Infectious Disease Diagnosis: HIV, hepatitis, rotavirus, and others.
  • Food Industry: Detection of food toxins and adulterants.
  • Research: Measurement of cytokines, hormones, and other biomarkers.

Reference:

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK555922/

questions.text: A 2-year-old unimmunized child presents with fever, runny nose, cough, red eyes, and small bluish-white lesions inside the mouth near the lower molars. The next day, a reddish rash appears, beginning on the face and neck. What is the structural nature of the virus responsible for this illness?
questions.solution:
The combination of fever, cough, conjunctivitis, Koplik spots (bluish-white spots in the buccal mucosa), followed by a spreading rash is classic for measles, caused by the measles virus, which belongs to the Paramyxoviridae family. It is an enveloped, single-stranded RNA virus.

Complications of Measles:

  • Secondary Bacterial Infections:
    • Measles weakens the immune system, increasing the risk of bacterial infections.
    • Common bacterial complications:
      • Middle ear infections (otitis media)
      • Lung infections (bronchopneumonia)
    • Reactivation or worsening of latent tuberculosis is possible.
  • Complications Caused Directly by the Measles Virus:
    • Severe lung infection in vulnerable individuals (Giant-cell pneumonitis or Hecht's pneumonia), especially in those with weakened immunity (e.g., HIV).
    • Airway inflammation (Acute laryngotracheobronchitis or croup).
    • Diarrhea can worsen malnutrition and lead to vitamin A deficiency.
  • Central Nervous System Complications:
    • Subacute sclerosing panencephalitis (SSPE): A rare, delayed complication that causes progressive brain damage.
    • Other possible brain-related issues:
      • Brain inflammation after measles (Post-measles encephalomyelitis)
      • Measles inclusion body encephalitis.

Explanation of other options:

Non-enveloped ssRNA (Option B): This structure is seen in viruses like enteroviruses and hepatitis A, which cause illnesses like gastroenteritis or hand-foot-mouth disease, not measles-like symptoms with rash and Koplik spots.

Non-enveloped dsRNA (Option C): Typical of rotavirus, which causes diarrhea and vomiting, not fever, conjunctivitis, mouth lesions, and rash characteristic of measles.

Enveloped dsRNA (Option D): Such viruses are not associated with human diseases resembling measles; enveloped dsRNA viruses are rare and do not present with this respiratory and rash illness.

questions.text: A truck driver presents with a painless, indurated genital ulcer after engaging in unprotected sexual activity. Which type of microscope is best suited to detect the motility of the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
The clinical picture suggests a primary syphilitic chancre, typically caused by Treponema pallidum, a spiral-shaped motile bacterium. This organism can be visualized in its motile form using dark-field microscopy, where it appears as slender, tightly coiled spirals with characteristic slow, corkscrew-like movement.

Specimen Collection and Diagnostic Methods for Syphilis:

  • Specimen Collection Procedure:
    • Clean the lesion using gauze soaked in warm saline.
    • Gently scrape the lesion margins to abrade the superficial epithelium.
    • Apply gentle pressure to the base of the lesion to collect exudate, avoiding contamination with blood.
    • Collect serum samples for serological testing.
    • If neurosyphilis is suspected, collect cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) for further testing.
  • Dark-Field Microscopy:
    • Place the collected exudate on a slide and cover with a coverslip.
    • Examine the sample under dark-field microscopy.
    • Treponema pallidum appears as slender, tightly coiled, spiral-shaped structures with characteristic slow, corkscrew-like motility.
  • Silver Impregnation Staining:
    • Fontana's Method: Used to stain smear samples from the lesion.
    • Levaditi's Method: Preferred for staining tissue sections to detect pallidum.

Explanation of other options:

Electron microscope (Option B): Gives highly magnified, detailed images of structures but is not practical for real-time observation of motility in clinical settings.

Light microscope (Option C): Cannot reliably visualize T. pallidum due to its small size and thin structure unless special stains are used; motility assessment is not possible.

Fluorescent microscope (Option D): Requires fluorescent dyes for detection; not routinely used for syphilis diagnosis as T. pallidum is usually identified by dark-field microscopy.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents with complaints of urethral discomfort and purulent discharge, as shown in the image below. He reports a history of unprotected sexual intercourse approximately one week ago. Based on the clinical presentation and image, what is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
The patient presents with classic features of gonococcal urethritis, including purulent, yellowish urethral discharge developing within 1 to 7 days of unprotected sexual contact.

Explanation of other options:

Ureaplasma urealyticum (Option B): Typically causes non-gonococcal urethritis with scant, mucoid, or clear discharge, not the thick, yellow purulent discharge seen in this case.

Herpes simplex virus (Option C): Usually presents with painful vesicles, ulcers, or lesions on the genitals; purulent urethral discharge alone is not the typical presentation.

Trichomonas vaginalis (Option D): Causes urethritis, but the discharge is often frothy, yellow-green, and foul-smelling, unlike the purulent, yellow discharge seen here with gonorrhea.

questions.text: A child presents with a scaly patch and hair loss on the scalp. A hair specimen sent for culture grows white, powdery colonies, and a hair perforation test performed on the isolate shows a positive result. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
The combination of white, powdery colonies on culture and a positive hair perforation test is characteristic of Trichophyton mentagrophytes. This fungus can penetrate and erode the hair shaft, demonstrated by the wedge-shaped perforations seen under microscopy.

Hair Perforation Test:

  • Purpose:
    • Used to distinguish between Trichophyton rubrum and Trichophyton mentagrophytes.
  • Procedure:
    • Place human hair strands in a petri dish containing 20 mL of distilled water.
    • Sterilize the dish by autoclaving.
    • Add sterile 10% yeast extract and fungal fragments to the hair.
    • Incubate at 25°C for 2 to 3 weeks.
    • Examine hair under the microscope using lactophenol cotton blue stain.
  • Interpretation of Results:
    • Positive Test:
      • Suggests the presence of mentagrophytes.
      • Hair shaft shows wedge-shaped perforations due to surface erosion.
    • Negative Test:
      • Indicates rubrum.
      • No characteristic perforations were seen.

Explanation of other options:

Trichophyton rubrum (Option A): Common in skin and nail infections, but produces reddish to yellowish colonies and shows a negative hair perforation test, making it unlikely here.

Trichophyton schoenleinii (Option B): Known for causing favus, a rare form of tinea capitis, but typically produces scaly, pale colonies and shows a negative hair perforation test.

Trichophyton violaceum (Option D): Causes tinea capitis but forms violet to purple colonies, not white powdery ones, and usually does not produce a positive hair perforation test.

questions.text: A wildlife photographer, recently returned from a trip to Africa, arrives at the emergency department with complaints of abdominal pain, an enlarged liver, and signs of bleeding. Despite receiving medical care, the patient died. Postmortem examination reveals the presence of intranuclear Torres bodies in the liver. Which of the following vaccines, containing the corresponding strain, could have prevented this illness?
questions.solution:
The clinical features in a person returning from an endemic area, along with liver biopsy showing Torres bodies, suggest a diagnosis of Yellow fever. The 17D strain vaccine is a live-attenuated preparation that offers reliable protection against this disease.

Explanation of other options:

Nakayama Strain (Option B): This strain is used to prepare vaccines for Japanese encephalitis, a mosquito-borne illness found mainly in Asia, unrelated to Yellow fever.

Weigl's Strain (Option C): This vaccine is designed to protect against epidemic typhus, a bacterial disease caused by Rickettsia prowazekii, not a viral hemorrhagic fever.

Jeryl Lynn Strain (Option D): The Jeryl Lynn strain is used for the mumps vaccine, which protects against a viral infection causing parotitis, not Yellow fever.

questions.text: A soldier presents with fever and a rash that began on the trunk and later spread to the limbs, notably sparing the palms and soles. On examination, lice infestation is noted. Which of the following organisms is most likely responsible for his illness?
questions.solution:
The presence of fever, trunk-to-limb rash sparing palms and soles, and louse infestation is characteristic of epidemic typhus caused by Rickettsia prowazekii.

Explanation of other options:

Rickettsia akari (Option A): Causes rickettsialpox, transmitted by mites, with a characteristic eschar at the bite site and a vesicular rash, not a trunk-to-extremity rash linked to lice.

Rickettsia conorii (Option B): Responsible for Indian tick typhus, transmitted by ticks, where the rash typically starts on the limbs (often including palms and soles) and spreads to the trunk, the opposite of this case.

Rickettsia typhi (Option D): Causes endemic typhus, spread by rat fleas, not lice, and outbreaks are usually isolated rather than epidemic in nature.

questions.text: A woman presents with thick, white, curd-like vaginal discharge. Microscopic examination of a vaginal smear reveals budding yeast cells along with pseudohyphae. Which of the following culture media can help in distinguishing the probable species of the organism responsible for this infection?
questions.solution:
The presence of thick, curd-like white vaginal discharge along with pseudohyphae and budding yeast on microscopic examination is suggestive of vulvovaginal candidiasis. CHROM agar is a specialized culture medium that enables the identification of different Candida species based on the distinct colony colors they produce.

Explanation of other options:

Bird seed Agar (Option A): Specifically used to isolate Cryptococcus neoformans, not for identifying or differentiating Candida species.

Brain Heart Infusion Agar (Option B): A rich medium for growing fastidious bacteria like Actinomyces, but not designed to distinguish fungal species.

Sabouraud Dextrose Agar (Option D): Supports fungal growth, including Candida, but all species produce similar-looking colonies, so it cannot differentiate between them.

questions.text: A 34-year-old male presents with profuse watery diarrhea, described as rice-water stools, after consuming contaminated water. The toxin responsible for this condition binds to which of the following receptors on intestinal epithelial cells?
questions.solution:
The clinical features of profuse watery diarrhea resembling rice-water stools point toward a diagnosis of cholera, caused by Vibrio cholerae. The cholera toxin binds to GM1 ganglioside receptors on intestinal epithelial cells, leading to excessive fluid loss.

Explanation of other options;

Cerebroganglioside (Option A): These gangliosides are primarily found in nerve tissues and play no role in cholera toxin binding or its mechanism.

GM2 ganglioside receptor (Option B): This receptor is linked to Tay-Sachs disease, a genetic disorder, and is not involved in cholera pathogenesis.

Sphingomyelin (Option D): A structural lipid present in cell membranes, but it does not function as a receptor for cholera toxin.

questions.text:
A patient from Delhi presents with high-grade fever, joint pain, pain behind the eyes, and a widespread petechial rash for the past 3 days. Laboratory findings show:
1. Hemoglobin: 9 g/dL
2. WBC Count: 9,000 cells/mm3
3. Platelet Count: 20,000 cells/mm3
4. Positive tourniquet test
What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The combination of fever, rash, significant thrombocytopenia, and a positive tourniquet test suggests Dengue Hemorrhagic Fever (DHF). DHF is marked by bleeding tendencies, low platelet counts (≤100,000/mm³), and evidence of plasma leakage such as hemoconcentration, pleural effusion, or ascites.

Explanation of other options:

Dengue fever (Option A): Classic dengue fever may cause fever, joint pain, and rash, but usually lacks severe thrombocytopenia or bleeding signs seen in this patient.

Dengue shock syndrome (Option C): This severe form of DHF presents with features of circulatory collapse, such as low blood pressure and poor perfusion, which are not evident here.

Malaria (Option D): Though malaria can cause fever and low platelets, it typically does not produce petechiae or a positive tourniquet test, which are more suggestive of a bleeding disorder like DHF.

Reference:

  1. https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s11910-022-01213-7
  2. https://journals.lww.com/annals-of-medicine-and-surgery/fulltext/2023/02000/acute_liver_failure_in_a_young_patient_with_dengue.46.aspx#
  3. https://symbiosisonlinepublishing.com/pulmonology-infectious-diseases/pulmonology-infectious-diseases10.php
  4. https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC4352732/#
  5. https://journals.lww.com/kleu/fulltext/2016/09030/dengue_fever_presenting_as_epididymo_orchitis.15.aspx

questions.text:
A child presents with fever and a rash. A microscopic examination of a urine sample reveals the following findings:

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The "owl-eye" appearance seen on microscopy refers to enlarged cells with prominent basophilic intranuclear inclusions, a classic finding in Cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection.

Explanation of other options:

Epstein-Barr virus (Option B): EBV causes infectious mononucleosis with features such as fever, sore throat, and lymphadenopathy, often with atypical lymphocytes in the blood, but not "owl-eye" inclusions.

Herpes simplex virus (Option C): HSV typically presents with vesicular lesions and multinucleated giant cells on smear, showing Cowdry type A inclusions, but not the classic "owl-eye" pattern.

Toxoplasma gondii (Option D): A protozoan parasite responsible for congenital toxoplasmosis, presenting with neurological signs like hydrocephalus and chorioretinitis, but its cysts do not demonstrate "owl-eye" inclusions.

Reference:

  1. https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/28089555/
  2. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK459185/
  3. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK482197/
  4. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK563286/

questions.text: A sewage worker reports with abdominal pain, jaundice, conjunctival redness, and hematuria for the past 5 days. Which of the following tests is the most appropriate to confirm the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical features of fever, jaundice, conjunctival suffusion, and hematuria in a sewage worker point towards a diagnosis of Leptospirosis. The most appropriate test to confirm this diagnosis is the Microscopic Agglutination Test (MAT).

Explanation of other options:

Widal test (Option A): This test detects antibodies against Salmonella typhi, the causative agent of typhoid fever, which does not match this patient's clinical features or exposure history.

Weil-Felix reaction (Option C): It is used for diagnosing Rickettsial infections, which typically present with fever and rash, but not with jaundice, hematuria, or conjunctival suffusion seen in leptospirosis.

Paul-Bunnell test (Option D): This test identifies heterophile antibodies in Epstein-Barr virus infections (infectious mononucleosis) and is unrelated to leptospiral infections.

Reference:

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK441858/

choices.text: CSF culture on chick embryo lines

questions.text: A patient presents with high-grade fever, altered mental status, headache, neck stiffness, and seizures. Clinical evaluation raises suspicion of Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV) encephalitis. Which of the following investigations is the most appropriate to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most sensitive and specific method for diagnosing HSV encephalitis is the detection of HSV DNA in cerebrospinal fluid using polymerase chain reaction (PCR).


Explanation of other options:

IgM in CSF (Option A): While antibodies may appear later, they are unreliable for early diagnosis and may produce false negatives in the initial phase.

Tzanck smear of CSF (Option B): Tzanck smear is designed to detect multinucleated giant cells in skin or mucosal lesions, not for diagnosing CNS infections using CSF samples.

CSF culture on chick embryo lines (Option D): HSV is typically cultured on human cell lines; culture from CSF is often low yield and not recommended as the primary diagnostic test in encephalitis.

Reference:

  1. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK557643/
  2. https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC5655652/

choices.text: Detection of microfilariae in the blood smear

questions.text: A patient presents with a history of fever and a positive filarial antigen test, suggestive of lymphatic filariasis. To confirm active infection, what should be the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A filarial antigen test indicates exposure to filarial infection but does not confirm active parasitemia. The next step is to perform a peripheral blood smear, preferably a thick smear collected at night, to detect circulating microfilariae, which confirms active infection. Giemsa or Wright’s stain is used to visualize the organisms.

Diagnostic Methods for Filariasis:

  • Thick Blood Smear (Preferred Method):
    • Ideal for detecting microfilariae in peripheral blood.
    • Best collected during night-time hours (10 PM to 2 AM) due to nocturnal periodicity.
    • Helps differentiate species based on morphology:
      • Wuchereria bancrofti: Smooth, gently curved body with clearly countable nuclei.
  • Brugia species: Smaller, sharply kinked body with indistinct, crowded nuclei.
  • Rapid Diagnostic Test (Filarial Antigen Detection):
    • Also called the filarial strip test.
    • Used for quick detection, monitoring, and surveillance programs.
    • Highly sensitive for Wuchereria bancrofti antigen.
  • Membrane Filtration Technique:
    • Highly sensitive for detecting low-density microfilaremia.
    • Blood is passed through a filter to concentrate microfilariae.
    • Requires laboratory expertise and specialized equipment.
  • DEC Provocation Test:
    • Involves administering a single dose of Diethylcarbamazine (100 mg).
    • Blood smear is taken 1 hour later to detect microfilariae, which may circulate during the day after DEC stimulation.
    • Offers high specificity but is less commonly used now.
  • Serological Tests:
    • Detect filarial antibodies.
    • Cannot reliably distinguish between past exposure and active infection.
  • Community Blood Surveys:
    • Involves large-scale screening using thick blood smears.
    • Primarily used for epidemiological mapping and assessing disease burden in endemic regions.

Explanation of other options:

Bone marrow biopsy (Option A): Not indicated in filariasis, as the parasite primarily affects the lymphatic system, not the bone marrow.

DEC provocation test (Option B): This test can stimulate microfilariae into circulation, but with reliable antigen tests and blood smear methods available, it is rarely used today.

Ultrasound of the scrotum (Option D): Useful in patients with scrotal swelling or hydrocele to detect the "filarial dance sign," but not part of the routine diagnostic confirmation following a positive antigen test.

Reference: https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC5154460/

questions.text: A 6-year-old child is brought to the clinic by his mother due to complaints of intense perianal itching, especially disturbing sleep at night. On examination, the physician performs a perianal swab using transparent adhesive tape. Microscopic analysis of the sample is shown in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical feature of nocturnal perianal itching, along with microscopy showing flattened-sided, colorless, ovoid eggs, points towards the diagnosis of Enterobius vermicularis (pinworm) infection.

Explanation of other options:

Ancylostoma (Option A): This hookworm causes iron deficiency anemia and gastrointestinal symptoms. It does not cause perianal itching or produce eggs with a flattened side.

Hymenolepis nana (Option C): The dwarf tapeworm leads to abdominal pain and diarrhea, especially in children. It does not cause perianal itching or show asymmetrical, flattened-sided eggs.

Necator americanus (Option D): This hookworm species also causes iron deficiency anemia and skin manifestations like ground itch, but it is not associated with perianal itching or eggs resembling those of Enterobius vermicularis.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presents with a long-standing history of fever, swelling, and skin discoloration over the lower limb. On microscopic examination of a peripheral blood smear is shown below. What is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution: The described microscopic feature is a sheathed microfilaria with no nuclei at the tip of the tail, which is characteristic of Wuchereria bancrofti, a parasite known to cause lymphatic filariasis (elephantiasis).

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant is brought to the clinic with a 3-day history of vomiting and watery diarrhea. Laboratory evaluation suggests a viral cause of gastroenteritis. Which of the following viral proteins is primarily responsible for the diarrheal symptoms in this child?
questions.solution:
The most likely causative agent in this scenario is rotavirus, a leading cause of diarrhea in young children. NSP4, a non-structural protein produced by rotavirus, functions as an enterotoxin. It disrupts intestinal epithelial cells by increasing chloride secretion and impairing electrolyte absorption, resulting in secretory diarrhea.

Explanation of other options:

NSP6 (Option B): A non-structural protein of rotavirus involved in viral replication and assembly, but it does not act as an enterotoxin or contribute directly to diarrhea.

VP3 (Option C): A structural protein with enzymatic activity that plays a role in capping viral RNA; it has no role in causing gastrointestinal symptoms.

VP4 (Option D): An outer capsid protein important for inducing neutralizing antibodies; it is structural, not responsible for diarrhea or enterotoxin activity.

questions.text: A 42-year-old farmer from a sub-Himalayan village presents with a slowly progressive, rough, warty growth over his lower leg. He recalls a thorn prick injury at the same site nearly a year ago. The lesion has gradually enlarged and now has a verrucous, cauliflower-like surface. A skin biopsy was performed, and the microscopic image is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical history of a chronic warty lesion developing after a thorn prick, along with biopsy showing sclerotic (copper penny) bodies, points towards a diagnosis of Chromoblastomycosis.

Explanation of other options:

Blastomycosis (Option A): This fungal infection primarily causes pulmonary disease and may have skin involvement, but biopsy shows broad-based budding yeast, not sclerotic bodies.

Phaeohyphomycosis (Option B): Though caused by pigmented fungi, histology reveals dark, septate hyphae within tissue, it does not show the characteristic round, copper-colored sclerotic bodies seen in Chromoblastomycosis.

Sporotrichosis (Option D): Typically follows lymphatic channels after traumatic inoculation, and microscopy reveals cigar-shaped yeast cells, which are distinct from the muriform bodies seen in this case.

Reference:

  1. Chromoblastomycosis - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf

questions.text: A child presents to the outpatient department with swelling, redness, and tenderness over the knee joint. History reveals that two weeks ago, the child had a febrile illness associated with bloody diarrhea. Which organism is most likely responsible for this presentation?
questions.solution:
The clinical features of bloody diarrhea followed by knee joint arthritis in this child point towards a diagnosis of Shigella-induced reactive arthritis (Reiter's syndrome).


Explanation of other options:

E.coli (Option A): While some strains like EHEC or EIEC can cause bloody diarrhea, E. coli is not commonly associated with reactive arthritis.

Giardia lamblia (Option C): Giardia leads to greasy, non-bloody, foul-smelling diarrhea due to malabsorption, but does not cause joint inflammation.

Rotavirus (Option D): Rotavirus typically causes watery diarrhea and vomiting in young children, without bloody stools or arthritis.

Reference:

  1. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK564298/
  2. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK513239/
  3. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK558951/

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents to the outpatient department with painful ulcers over the genital area. The ulcers have irregular, soft margins with a yellowish exudate. On examination, tender, enlarged inguinal lymph nodes are noted. The patient is sexually active and reports no prior similar episodes. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
The patient has classical features of chancroid, a sexually transmitted infection caused by Haemophilus ducreyi. It typically presents with painful, soft genital ulcers and tender inguinal lymphadenopathy (bubo formation).

Haemophilus ducreyi:

  • Small, gram-negative coccobacillus.
  • Requires X factor for growth; does not need V factor.
  • Displays bipolar staining (appears like a safety pin).
  • Characteristic arrangement seen on Gram stain: "school of fish" or "railroad track" pattern.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Painful genital ulcer with:
      • Soft, ragged edges.
      • Purulent base (may produce discharge).
    • Enlarged, tender lymph nodes in the groin (bubo formation).
  • Incubation period: Typically 3 to 10 days.
  • Diagnosis:
    • Primarily based on clinical signs.
    • Gram stain of ulcer exudate may reveal characteristic bacteria.
    • Culture on special media (technically demanding with low sensitivity).
    • PCR testing is considered the most sensitive diagnostic option.
  • Treatment:
    • Single-dose options:
      • Azithromycin 1g orally.
      • Ceftriaxone 250mg intramuscularly.
    • Alternative regimens:
      • Ciprofloxacin 500mg orally twice daily for 3 days.
      • Erythromycin 500mg orally three times daily for 7 days.
    • Treatment of sexual contacts is essential to prevent reinfection.

Explanation of other options:

Treponema pallidum (Option A): Causes syphilis, which presents with a painless, indurated, clean-base ulcer called a chancre, unlike the painful ulcer in this case.

Chlamydia trachomatis (Option B): Causes small, often unnoticed, painless ulcers initially, with painful lymphadenopathy developing later, unlike the prominent painful ulcer seen here.

Lymphogranuloma venereum (Option D): Another name for the disease caused by Chlamydia trachomatis L1-L3 serovars; the initial ulcer is painless, making it unlikely here.

Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK537282/

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents with a painless swelling in the submandibular region, three days after a dental extraction. On incision and drainage, a foul-smelling discharge containing yellow-colored granules is observed. What is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
The clinical features of a painless submandibular swelling with foul-smelling discharge and yellow granules following tooth extraction point towards a diagnosis of Actinomyces israelii infection.

Actinomycetes israelii:

  • Acid-Fastness: Non-acid-fast
  • Oxygen Requirement: Anaerobic
  • Habitat:
    • Normal flora of the oral cavity
    • Infections typically arise endogenously
  • Risk Factors:
    • Can infect even immunocompetent individuals
  • Clinical Forms:
    • Commonly presents as cervicofacial infections
    • Can also cause abdominal and other systemic infections
  • Granules:
    • Characteristic yellow sulfur granules
    • Hard, non-emulsifiable
    • Composed of branching filamentous bacilli
    • Surrounded by club-like projections giving a sun-ray appearance
  • Culture Characteristics:
    • Solid media: Spidery molar tooth appearance
    • Liquid media: Fluffy ball formation at the bottom
  • Treatment:
    • Penicillin is the drug of choice

Explanation of other options:

Fonsecaea pedrosoi (Option A): Causes chromoblastomycosis, a chronic fungal skin infection seen after trauma, typically presenting as warty lesions on the lower limbs, not submandibular swellings or sulfur granules.

Mucor (Option B): Responsible for mucormycosis, an aggressive fungal infection affecting the sinuses, orbit, or brain, especially in diabetics or immunocompromised, with rapid tissue necrosis, not a slow, painless mass with granules.

Histoplasma capsulatum (Option C): Causes histoplasmosis, a pulmonary or systemic fungal infection acquired by inhalation of spores from bat or bird droppings, not associated with dental infections or sulfur granules.

questions.text: A man with a history of international travel presents with prolonged, unexplained fever. A bone marrow aspirate was performed, and the microscopic image is shown below. Which of the following tests is the most appropriate next step in confirming the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical features of prolonged, unexplained fever, history of travel to endemic regions, along with bone marrow findings showing Leishman-Donovan (LD) bodies, intracellular, ovoid amastigotes with a characteristic double-dot appearance (nucleus and kinetoplast) within macrophages point towards a diagnosis of Visceral Leishmaniasis (Kala-azar) caused by Leishmania donovani.


Explanation of other options:

pLDH (Option B): This test detects Plasmodium lactate dehydrogenase, used for diagnosing malaria, not visceral leishmaniasis.

Galactose lectin antigen (Option C): This antigen is used to diagnose Entamoeba histolytica infection (amoebiasis), unrelated to this clinical scenario or bone marrow findings.

HRP-2 antigen (Option D): Detects Histidine-Rich Protein 2 of Plasmodium falciparum, useful for malaria diagnosis, not for kala-azar.

choices.text: Pigmented, septate hyphae branching at right angles, Mucor species
Septate hyphae with right-angle branching, Fusarium species
Broad, aseptate hyphae branching at acute angles, Rhizopus species
Narrow, septate hyphae with acute angle branching, Aspergillus species

questions.text: A patient presents with fever, shortness of breath, palpitations, and tachycardia. Echocardiography shows vegetations attached to the septal leaflet of the heart valve. A tissue biopsy from the vegetation is examined microscopically, and the findings are shown below. Based on the morphology, which organism is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
The classic microscopic feature of Aspergillus species is narrow, septate hyphae branching at acute (typically ~45°) angles, often described as dichotomous branching. It is a known cause of fungal endocarditis, particularly in immunocompromised individuals or those with prosthetic valves.


Explanation of other options:

Septate hyphae with right-angle branching, Fusarium species (Option B): Characterized by hyaline, septate hyphae, but its hallmark is the presence of sickle-shaped macroconidia, not just right-angle branching; it mainly causes keratitis and bloodstream infections.

questions.text: A gardener presents with nodular, ulcerative lesions along the lymphatic channels of the arm. A microscopy image from a lesion biopsy is shown below. What is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
The clinical features of nodular lesions in a gardener, along with biopsy showing cigar-shaped yeast cells, point towards a diagnosis of Sporotrichosis.


Explanation of other options:

Histoplasmosis (Option B): Caused by Histoplasma capsulatum, typically presents with pulmonary symptoms or disseminated disease. Microscopy shows intracellular yeast within macrophages, not cigar-shaped yeast or lymphatic spread.


Blastomycosis (Option C): Caused by Blastomyces dermatitidis, affects lungs, skin, and bones. Yeast form shows broad-based budding, not cigar-shaped yeast, and lymphatic spread is less typical.


Coccidioidomycosis (Option D): Caused by Coccidioides species, primarily presents as a respiratory illness. Histology shows spherules filled with endospores, not cigar-shaped yeast or lymphocutaneous lesions.

questions.text: A 29-year-old female presents with complaints of lower abdominal pain radiating to the flanks along with dysuria. She reports a history of intermittent painless hematuria. Urine microscopy reveals the following structure, as shown below. A CT scan shows extensive calcifications of the urinary bladder. Which of the following parasites is most likely responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
The presence of terminal-spined eggs in urine along with bladder calcification points to Schistosoma haematobium, which resides in the bladder venous plexus.


Explanation of other options:

Fasciola hepatica (Option D): A liver fluke that infects the bile ducts, causing hepatobiliary disease (fascioliasis); it has no role in bladder pathology or eggs with terminal spines.

Reference:

  1. Relationship between Schistosomiasis and Bladder Cancer - PMC
  2. Schistosoma - an overview | ScienceDirect Topics
  3. Schistosoma intercalatum bilharziasis: clinical and epidemiological considerations
  4. Schistosoma Mekongi - an overview | ScienceDirect Topics

questions.text: A 54-year-old farmer from Ohio presents with a chronic cough and fatigue. Chest X-ray shows a cavitary lesion with hilar lymphadenopathy. A biopsy from the lymph node is obtained, and staining with lactophenol cotton blue reveals the findings shown below. Based on the clinical presentation and microscopic findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical features of chronic cough with cavitary lung lesion and hilar lymphadenopathy, along with biopsy showing tuberculate macroconidia, point towards a diagnosis of Histoplasmosis.

Explanation of other options:

Coccidioidomycosis (Option B): This fungus is endemic to the Southwestern USA (e.g., California, Arizona), not Ohio. Biopsy typically shows large spherules containing endospores, not the tuberculate macroconidia seen with Histoplasma.

Cryptococcus (Option C): Cryptococcus neoformans primarily causes meningitis in immunocompromised individuals and does not typically produce cavitary lung lesions with hilar lymphadenopathy. Microscopy reveals encapsulated yeast, not intracellular yeast with tuberculate macroconidia.

Blastomycosis (Option D): While it can cause lung lesions, it is more common near the Great Lakes and Mississippi River, not Ohio. Histology shows broad-based budding yeast, which differs from the small intracellular yeast and tuberculate macroconidia of Histoplasma.

Reference: Histoplasmosis

questions.text: A patient presents with complaints of abdominal pain and profuse watery diarrhea following a recent hospital stay for cellulitis. The patient was discharged on clindamycin. Two days later, these symptoms developed. Laboratory findings reveal an elevated total leukocyte count along with increased inflammatory markers (ESR and CRP). An endoscopic image of the colon is shown below. Based on the history and endoscopic findings, what is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
The clinical features, recent antibiotic use, along with endoscopy showing yellowish-white pseudomembranes over the colonic mucosa, point towards a diagnosis of pseudomembranous colitis caused by Clostridioides difficile.

Pseudomembranous Colitis:

  • Caused by Clostridioides difficile overgrowth after antibiotic use.
  • Results in inflammation of the colon with formation of whitish-yellow plaques on the mucosa.
  • Plaque Characteristics
    • Size: 1-2 mm or may cover larger mucosal areas.
    • Composed of:
      • Necrotic inflammatory cells (mainly leukocytes)
      • Fibrin
      • Mucus
      • Cellular debris
  • Toxins Involved:
    • Toxin A (enterotoxin) and Toxin B (cytotoxin) are produced.
    • These toxins damage cells by disrupting the actin cytoskeleton, leading to:
      • Loss of cell shape
      • Reduced cell adhesion
      • Weakened intestinal barrier

Explanation of other options:

Escherichia coli (Option A): Although certain strains like EHEC can cause diarrhea, they are not typically linked to recent antibiotic use and rarely present with pseudomembranes on endoscopy.

Norovirus (Option B): This viral infection causes acute gastroenteritis but is unrelated to antibiotic use and does not produce the characteristic pseudomembranous colitis seen here.

Rotavirus (Option D): Primarily affects infants and young children, not adults, and is not associated with antibiotic use or pseudomembrane formation on endoscopy.

Reference:

Colitis due to Clostridium difficile toxins

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman presents with pale patches over her chest that have gradually increased in size and coalesced. The lesions are mostly asymptomatic, but she is concerned about the cosmetic appearance. A potassium hydroxide (KOH) mount of skin scrapings shows the following microscopic findings as shown below. Which of the following organisms is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
The clinical features of hypopigmented patches along with microscopy showing the characteristic "spaghetti and meatballs" appearance point towards a diagnosis of Tinea versicolor caused by Malassezia.

Tinea Versicolor (Pityriasis Versicolor):

  • Type: Superficial fungal infection affecting the outer skin layer (stratum corneum).
  • Symptoms: Usually asymptomatic; may cause visible skin color changes.
  • Common in: Tropical climates, often seen in young adults.
  • Causative organism: Malassezia furfur
  • Clinical Features:
    • Flat, patchy skin lesions that may merge together.
    • Color changes seen as either lighter (hypopigmented) or darker (hyperpigmented) areas.
  • Commonly affected sites:
    • Chest, abdomen, upper limbs, and back

Explanation of other options:

Trichophyton (Option B): This genus causes dermatophytosis like ringworm or tinea infections but shows septate hyphae and microconidia on microscopy, not the classic "spaghetti and meatballs" appearance.

Chlamydospores (Option C): These are thick-walled resting spores seen in Candida species, not a separate organism, and are not associated with the spaghetti and meatballs pattern seen in Tinea versicolor.

Candida (Option D): Candida appears as budding yeast with pseudohyphae and is known for causing oral thrush or cutaneous candidiasis, but it does not show the short curved hyphae and clustered yeast cells seen in Malassezia infections.
